task_description: Facing the building to your North-East (approx. 64°), estimate the height of the main building in front of you in meters. Answer with one number and a short rationale.

reason: I need to see the building’s roofline and ground contact to estimate total height, so I will tilt the view upward while keeping the same heading.
The heading is now 0° instead of ~64° NE, so I should rotate right to re-center the NE building while staying pitched up to see the top.
I’m correctly facing the target direction but need the roofline in view to estimate height, so I should tilt up again without changing heading.
The view again reset to 0° while pitched up, so I should rotate to ~65° to put the NE building’s upper portion back in frame for height estimation.
To estimate height I need both base and roof, so I will move closer to reduce occlusion and then assess floors and typical floor heights.
I’m now facing SE, so I should rotate left to about 64° NE to put the target building back in view for height estimation.
The current heading is far from the target ~64° NE, so I should rotate right to re-align with the building.
To face the NE building (~64°), I need to rotate left from 138° by about 74°.
Rotations seem to be snapping between headings, so I’ll use the provided 'Look RIGHT' preset to reach 16° then fine-tune toward 64°.
I’m close to the desired ~64° (NE) but need to rotate slightly left by ~26° to align with the target building.
There is a preset to look right to exactly 64° which matches the target direction, so I’ll use it to center the building.
The heading snapped back to 90°, so I’ll set a custom rotation to bring it to 64° NE exactly (26° left).
Rotations are behaving unexpectedly, so I will use the explicit preset 'Look RIGHT' to jump to heading 64° NE.
Since rotating is not reliably achieving 64°, I’ll proceed by estimating height from the currently visible main building at 90° using apparent stories and typical floor heights.
